docs.lead_paragraph: Natural Gas Prices Surge to a Record; Home Heating Bills Are Bound to Rise Natural gas prices set a record yesterday, pointing to sharply higher heating bills for a majority of Americans this winter and soaring costs for makers of energy-intensive industrial products like plastics and chemicals. According to recent estimates by the Department of Energy, Americans are likely to pay about $400 more for their natural gas this winter than last year, analysts warn the figures might be even higher. [Page C1.] Bayou Fund Group Executives Surrender and Plead Guilty The founders of the Bayou Group, Samuel Israel III, the chief executive, and Daniel Marino, the former chief financial officer, entered guilty pleas to investment adviser fraud, mail fraud and conspiracy. [C1.] KPMG to Pay $195 Million to Settle Tax Shelter Claims The accounting firm KPMG and a law firm have agreed to pay $195 million to about 280 wealthy investors who bought four types of questionable tax shelters, the first major step by the two firms to deal with billions of dollars in potential civil claims. [C1.] Lenovo Realigns Management to Integrate I.B.M. PC Unit Five months after Lenovo bought the personal computer unit of I.B.M., the operations are being melded together in earnest as the company tries to chart a path to success. Lenovo plans to announce a management realignment intended to advance a strategy that emphasizes notebook PC's, exploiting the fast-growing markets of China and India, and a move into the American consumer market early next year with Lenovo-branded machines. [C1.] Investors Worry as Pfizer's Problems Grow With Pfizer facing a new lawsuit, possible generic competition to one of its top-selling drugs and a thin pipeline of developing drugs, its stock is near an eight-year low and its investors are becoming concerned. Market Place. [C3.] E*Trade Financial Acquires a J.P. Morgan Unit E*Trade Financial said it would acquire BrownCo, a division of J.P. Morgan Chase, for $1.6 billion in cash, to gain access to the firm's affluent and active trading customers. R. Jarrett Lilien, left, E*Trade's president and chief operating officer, said consolidation in the brokerage industry was overdue and with the acquisition E*Trade would develop a base of customers ''that a few years from now will have accounts with a million dollars or more.'' This most recent deal follows E*Trade's purchase of Harrisdirect and Ameritrade's merger with TD Waterhouse this year. [C15.] General Electric Buys Medical Software Maker The General Electric Company said its health care unit would buy the IDX Systems Corporation, which makes software for hospitals and doctors' offices, in a deal the companies valued at $1.2 billion. [C15.] Two Large New York Area Health Insurers to Merge Two of the region's biggest health insurers, Health Insurance Plan of New York and Group Health Inc., announced that they planned to merge. [B3] Ford to Cut Number of Parts Suppliers by Half The Ford Motor Company said it planned to cut in half the number of companies supplying major auto parts in its latest move to cut costs. [C3.] Stocks Gain on Positive Earnings Forecasts Stocks rose as better-than-expected earnings forecasts suggested that profit growth can withstand higher energy prices. The Dow Jones industrial average added 79.69 points, to 10,552.78. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.79 points, to 1,227.68. The Nasdaq gained 25.82, to 2,141.22. [C6.] Trade Show Features Phones That Store Music The hot topic among mobile phone executives gathered for a cellphone trade show is the push to transform handsets into portable music players. [C4.] PepsiCo Posts 13 Percent Quarterly Sales Rise PepsiCo reported its biggest quarterly sales gain in three and a half years as hot weather in the United States spurred demand for Gatorade sports drinks, Lipton tea and Aquafina water. PepsiCo said sales rose 13 percent, to $8.18 billion, and its net income, excluding one-time items, was higher than analysts had expected and its shares rose 2.6 percent. [C5.] Samsung Plans $33 Billion in New Chip Lines Samsung Electronics said it would spend $33 billion to build nine new chip lines in South Korea by 2012, creating 14,000 jobs and going against a tide of cutbacks at its Japanese rivals, Sony and Sanyo. [C4.] Canadian Court Opens Door to Tobacco Claims A ruling by Canada's Supreme Court has opened the door for the province of British Columbia to sue tobacco companies in an effort to recover the cost of smoking-related health care. [C4.] Cable Movie Channel Ads Court Young Viewers The cable television channel TCM, formerly Turner Classic Movies, is starting an advertising campaign aimed at getting younger viewers to watch old classic movies. Advertising. Stuart Elliot. [C5.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Two of the region's biggest health insurers, Health Insurance Plan of New York and Group Health Inc., announced yesterday that they planned to merge, raising new questions about an expected multibillion-dollar windfall for New York State from HIP's planned conversion to a profit-making company. State officials have talked of reaping $2 billion to $3 billion from the HIP conversion. If the combined company became profit-making one, it might produce much more money for the state, but some experts said merger plans also raised doubts about whether a conversion would take place at all.

headline.main: Insurers' Merger Plans Raise Questions About an Expected Windfall for New York State

docs.snippet: The merger of Health Insurance Plan of New York and Group Health Inc. is expected to result in a multibillion-dollar windfall from HIP's planned conversion to a profit-making company.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reversing her earlier decision, a federal judge ruled that companies may offer younger retirees better health care benefits than they give older retirees who qualify for Medicare. The AARP sued over the rule change proposed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on the ground that unequal health packages amount to age discrimination.
docs.abstract: Judge Anita B Brody, reversing her earlier decision, rules that companies may offer younger retirees better health care benefits than they give older retirees who qualify for Medicare; AARP sued over rule change proposed by Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on ground that unequal health packages amount to age discrimination (S)
docs.snippet: A federal judge ruled that companies may offer younger retirees better health care benefits than they give older retirees who qualify for Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Martin O'Malley, whose tough anticrime message helped propel him to two decisive election victories in Baltimore, began his campaign for Maryland governor on Wednesday evening, saying the state had gone ''adrift'' and needed new leadership. Mr. O'Malley capped a day of campaigning in the Maryland suburbs of Washington with his announcement in Patterson Park in East Baltimore, declaring: ''Maryland is adrift. It's time to get Maryland moving again because we know a stronger Maryland can do better.''

headline.main: Baltimore Mayor Announces His Candidacy for Governor

docs.snippet: Mayor Martin O'Malley began his campaign for Maryland governor on Wednesday evening, saying the state had gone "adrift" and needed new leadership.

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Guard has only a third of the equipment it needs to respond to domestic disasters and terrorist attacks and will need $7 billion to acquire the radios, trucks, construction machinery and medical gear required, the Guard's top commander told a Congressional committee on Wednesday. Lt. Gen. H Steven Blum, chief of the National Guard Bureau, said that after Hurricane Katrina, guardsmen using old radios were unable to talk to active-duty troops with the latest communications systems as they patrolled New Orleans.

headline.main: At Hearings, States and National Guard Make Appeals for Aid

docs.snippet: The National Guard has only a third of the equipment it needs to respond to domestic disasters and terrorist attacks and will need $7 billion to acquire the radios, trucks, construction machinery and medical gear required, the Guard's top commander...

byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE; Edmund L. Andrews and David E. Rosenbaum contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Public universities and governments can provide health insurance to the partners of gay and lesbian employees without violating the Michigan Constitution, a judge ruled Tuesday. The ruling sets aside a legal opinion issued this year by Attorney General Mike Cox saying that the City of Kalamazoo could not provide benefits to gay partners. Mr. Cox cited the constitutional amendment approved by voters in November that made the union between a man and a woman the only agreement recognized as a marriage ''or similar union for any purpose.'' Twenty-one gay and lesbian couples who work for Kalamazoo, universities and the state sued, challenging Mr. Cox's interpretation. The judge, Joyce Draganchuk of Ingham County Circuit Court, said the purpose of the amendment was to ban same-sex marriage and civil unions, not to keep public employers from offering benefits to gay and lesbian employees.

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Judge Rules For Same-Sex Couples

docs.abstract: Michigan Judge Joyce Draganchuk rules public universities and governments can provide health insurance to partners of gay and lesbian employees without violating state constitution; ruling supersedes legal opinion issued by State Atty Gen Mike Cox saying City of Kalamazoo could not provide gay partner benefits (S)
